images.copyright: Red deer stag in De Hoge Veluwe National Park, Netherlands (© CreativeNature_nl/Getty Images)
images.title: Info
images.caption: Red deer stag in De Hoge Veluwe National Park, Netherlands
images.desc: Picture 55 square kilometres of open land, wildlife on the move and a stag flaunting its crown of antlers. In 1909, husband and wife Anton Kröller and Helene Kröller-Müller began building a private estate in Gelderland, Netherlands—what we now know as De Hoge Veluwe National Park. Their vision? To merge art and nature. They brought it to life by placing artwork within the landscape, like 'Three Upright Motives' by English sculptor Henry Moore in the Pampelse Zand and the President Steyn stone bench by Belgian architect Henry van de Velde, among others.

images.copyright: Val Brandet, Brescia, Lombardy, Italy (© ClickAlps/Alamy)
images.title: Info
images.caption: Val Brandet, Brescia, Lombardy, Italy
images.desc: Some valleys ask to be explored; Val Brandet in Lombardy, Italy, invites you to slow down and listen. Tucked inside Adamello Park and part of the municipality of Corteno Golgi—named after Nobel Prize–winning physician Camillo Golgi—this valley balances science and scenery, memory and movement.

og.title: Val Brandet, Brescia, Lombardy, Italy

images.copyright: Eastbourne Pier, East Sussex, England (© Tolga_TEZCAN/Getty Images)
images.title: Info
images.caption: Eastbourne Pier, England
images.desc: When it comes to seaside icons, England's Eastbourne Pier doesn't just make waves—it has been riding them for over 150 years. Opened in 1870, this Victorian marvel in East Sussex has survived tempests, fires and even wars. Stretching gracefully into the English Channel, the pier started life as a docking point for steamers. Over time, it evolved into a place where you can stroll above the water, lose a few coins to an arcade machine and gain a few back in memories.

og.title: Eastbourne Pier, England
og.desc: When it comes to seaside icons, England's Eastbourne Pier doesn't just make waves—it has been riding them for over 150 years. Opened in…

images.copyright: Olive orchard in the Serra de Tramuntana, Mallorca, Balearic Islands, Spain (© cinoby/Getty Images)
images.title: Info
images.caption: Olive orchard in the Serra de Tramuntana, Mallorca, Balearic Islands, Spain
images.desc: Ancient yet vibrant, twisted yet resilient, olive trees can live for over a thousand years. Even when scarred or hollowed, their trunks still send out fresh leaves each season—a living record of survival through drought, wind and fire. Olives have carried both practical and symbolic weight through the ages: their oil was pressed for anointing, medicine and daily sustenance; crowns of their leaves graced Olympic victors; and their branches became a lasting emblem of peace.

og.title: Olive orchard in the Serra de Tramuntana, Mallorca, Balearic Islands, Spain
og.desc: Ancient yet vibrant, twisted yet resilient, olive trees can live for over a thousand years. Even when scarred or hollowed, their trunks…

images.copyright: The Trevi Fountain in Rome, Italy (© Nico De Pasquale Photography/Getty Images)
images.title: Info
images.caption: Trevi Fountain, Rome, Italy
images.desc: Ever heard coins clinking louder than applause? That's the Trevi Fountain in Rome, Italy, for you—a spot where history, hope and selfie sticks collide. Completed in 1762, it marks the endpoint of one of ancient Rome's earliest aqueducts, the Aqua Virgo, which still supplies water today. The name 'Trevi' comes from Tre Vie—'three roads'—signifying the junction where it stands. Designed by Italian architect Nicola Salvi and finished by Giuseppe Pannini, this 26-metre marvel is the largest Baroque fountain in the city and one of the most famous in the world. Its sculptures show Oceanus, the god of the sea, surrounded by Tritons and horses.

og.title: Trevi Fountain, Rome, Italy

images.copyright: Gwalior Fort, Madhya Pradesh, India (© ImagesofIndia/Shutterstock)
images.title: Info
images.caption: Gwalior Fort, Madhya Pradesh, India
images.desc: Gwalior, in Madhya Pradesh, is not just a city; it is a chapter of India's history. Towering over the skyline, Gwalior Fort is a 6th-century hill fort shaped by generations of rulers and wrapped in legend. Nicknamed 'the Gibraltar of India,' this fort was praised by Mughal emperor Babur as the 'pearl among the fortresses of Hind' for its strength and grandeur. The fort has seen rulers from the Tomars to the Mughals and is linked to battles, royal intrigue and hidden treasures.

images.title: Info
images.caption: Ammonite fossil from Madagascar
images.desc: Look closely at this ammonite fossil. Its swirling shell, once home to a prehistoric sea creature, holds a mathematical secret—a spiral pattern. Each new chamber is proportionally larger than the previous one, maintaining a consistent growth ratio, often associated with the Fibonacci sequence.

images.copyright: Monte Sirente, Abruzzo, Italy (© ValerioMei/Getty Images)
images.title: Info
images.caption: Monte Sirente, Abruzzo, Italy
images.desc: Mount Sirente stands proudly in the heart of Abruzzo, in Italy, with its peak touching the clear sky and its slopes cloaked in forests. At 2,349 metres, Mount Sirente dominates the landscape of the Sirente-Velino Regional Park, amid silent valleys and karst plateaus. Its massive, almost trapezoidal shape speaks of ancient geological origins and a mysterious crater, possibly caused by a meteorite that fell thousands of years ago.
